tn.text: The word "Behold" here alerts us to pay attention to the surprising information that follows.

tn.ref: like the sound of many waters
tn.text: See how you translated "Like the noise of rushing water" in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:01:24|1:24]].
"the earth was full of bright light"
The word "It" refers to the vision of the glory of God coming from the east.

tn.ref: when he had come to destroy the city
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) "when the God of Israel had come to destroy the city" or 2) "when I had come to see the God of Israel destroy the city."
Here "corpses" refers to the idols that the people's kings worshiped. The idols are called corpses because they are not alive. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"The house of Israel profaned"
See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:05:09|5:9]].
This phase means "I completely destroyed them because I was angry." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

"this pattern" or "this plan"
See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:21:06|21:6]].

tn.ref: will keep to all its design
tn.text: "will keep the pattern"
"the instruction" or "the rule"
The word "border" probably refers to the wall that goes all the way around the temple.
"absolutely holy"
The word "Behold" here adds emphasis to what follows. It can also be translated as "Indeed!"

tn.ref: The border around its surrounding edge
tn.text: "The border going around its edge"

tn.ref: This will be the base of the altar
tn.text: "These will be the measurements of the base of the altar."
"the bottom supporting the altar" or "the foundation of the altar"
a narrow and flat surface that sticks out from a wall
the place where sacrifices were either cooked or burnt up with fire
The horns were the parts of the altar at the four corners of the altar that stuck up above the rest of the altar.
"Yahweh said"
See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:02:01|2:3]].
"rules" or "instructions"
The word "you" is singular. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
See how you translated "you" in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:43:18|43:19]].

See how you translated "You" in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:43:18|43:19]].

This phrase is used here to mark an important part of the instructions. If your language has a way for doing this, you could consider using it here.

tn.ref: your burnt offerings ... your peace offerings ... accept you
tn.text: The words "yours" and "you" are second person plural and refer to the people of Israel in general. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
"will receive you with favor" or "will be pleased with you"
